ElementDescription: The NDAR Global Unique Identifier (GUID) for research subject
Subject ID how it's defined in lab/project
Date on which the interview/genetic test/sampling/imaging/biospecimen was completed. MM/DD/YYYY
Age in months at the time of the interview/test/sampling/imaging.
Notes: Age is rounded to chronological month. If the research participant is 15-days-old at time of interview, the appropriate value would be 0 months. If the participant is 16-days-old, the value would be 1 month.
M = Male; F = Female; O=Other; NR = Not reported

ElementDescription: Study; The code for each individual study
Is the child taking any psychotropic medications?
Number of times per day patient must take medications

Notes: 1=regular short acting mg; 2=long acting SR/ER/XR mg; 3=mL; 4=patch cm; -9 =NK

ElementDescription: Is this form about a change to a dosing schedule or a stopped medicine?
The old schedule was too complicated; you need a simpler schedule (for example fewer times per day)
I didn't want my child to take the medicine on weekends
Other administration problems: e.g., it was hard to take it during the day (at school) or there was no one to supervise when the medication had to be taken.
My child got better so he/she didn't need the same amount.
The medicine didn't really help his/her problems.
The medicine didn't work as well it had before.
It was hard to get the medicine as prescribed.
What side effects does he/she experience?
Which of these reasons was the most important one for changing the dosage?
I was giving my child a "drug holiday" - a break from being on medicine.
I got tired of having my child take the medicine.
My child didn't like taking the medicine.
I don't think that it is good for young children to take medicines like this.
Other people in the family thought my child shouldn't take the medicine.
My child was not taking the medicine correctly (i.e., was abusing the medication, giving it to his friends, selling it, etc.)
Which of these reasons was the most important one for stopping the medicine?
Were there any ADHD medication monitoring visits during this interval?

Notes: 28 = Pharmacotherapist; 30 = Pediatrician; 31 = Family Doctor; 33 = Nurse or Nurse Practitioner; 34 = Physician's Assistant; 35 = Psychiatrist; 48 = Psychiatrist or Psychologist (respondent unable to specify); 49 = Neurologist; 99 = Other

ElementDescription: How many days a week does the child take this medication?

Notes: 1= Never; 2= Some days; 3= Most days; 4= Every day
